As an AI language model, I cannot provide legal advice, but it is understandable to be cautious about hiring a financial advisor to help with estate planning. However, it's important to note that most financial advisors are committed to helping their clients achieve their goals and are held to certain ethical standards and codes of conduct.

To find a reliable financial advisor, you can research firms and individuals in your area, read reviews, and ask for referrals from people you trust. It's also a good idea to ask about their qualifications, experience, and the types of clients they typically work with.

When it comes to estate planning specifically, many financial advisors will offer a free initial consultation to discuss your needs and goals, and to help you determine whether an estate planning service is right for you. This can be a good opportunity to ask questions and get a better sense of what's involved in the process.

Ultimately, the decision to work with a professional is a personal one, and it depends on your individual circumstances and preferences. However, it's important to remember that creating an effective estate plan involves more than simply drafting a will - it may require complex legal and financial considerations that are difficult to navigate on your own. Considering the long-term benefits and peace of mind that come with a comprehensive estate plan, the cost of working with a professional may be worth it for many individuals.
